column1: The Eyalet of Egypt operated as an administrative division of the Ottoman Empire from 1517 to 1867. It originated as a result of the conquest of Mamluk Egypt by the Ottomans in 1517
column2: following the Ottoman–Mamluk War (1516–1517) and the absorption of Syria into the Empire in 1516. The Ottomans administered Egypt as an eyalet of the their Empire (Ottoman Turkish: ایالت مصر‎‎ Eyālet-i Mıṣr) from 1517 until 1867
column3: with an interruption during the French occupation of 1798 to 1801.

column1: Egypt always proved a difficult province for the Ottoman Sultans to control
column2: due in part to the continuing power and influence of the Mamluks
column3: the Egyptian military caste who had ruled the country for centuries. As such
column4: Egypt remained semi-autonomous under the Mamluks until Napoleon Bonaparte's French forces invaded in 1798. After Anglo-Turkish forces expelled the French in 1801
column5: Muhammad Ali Pasha
column6: an Albanian military commander of the Ottoman army in Egypt
column7: seized power in 1805.

column1: Egypt under the Muhammad Ali dynasty remained nominally an Ottoman province. In reality
column2: the eyalet was practically independent
column3: and actually went to war twice with the empire - in 1831-33 and 1839-41. Constantinople granted Egypt the status of an autonomous vassal state or Khedivate in 1867. Isma'il Pasha (Khedive from 1863 to 1879) and Tewfik Pasha (Khedive from 1879 to 1892) governed Egypt as a quasi-independent state under Ottoman suzerainty until the British occupation of 1882. Nevertheless
column4: the Khedivate of Egypt (1867–1914) remained a de jure Ottoman province until 5 November 1914
column5: when it was declared by the British Empire a British protectorate in reaction to the Young Turks of the Ottoman Empire joining the First World War on the side of the Central Powers (October–November  1914).

column1: After the conquest of Egypt in 1517
column2: the Ottoman Sultan Selim I left the country. Grand Vizier Yunus Pasha was awarded the governorship of Egypt. However
column3: the sultan soon discovered that Yunus Pasha had created an extortion and bribery syndicate
column4: and gave the office to Hayır Bey
column5: the former Mamluk governor of Aleppo
column6: who had contributed to the Ottoman victory at the Battle of Marj Dabiq.The history of early Ottoman Egypt is a competition for power between the Mamluks and the representatives of the Ottoman Sultan.

column1: The register by which a great portion of the land was a fief of the Mamluks was left unchanged
column2: allowing the Mamluks to quickly return to positions of great influence. The Mamluk emirs were to be retained in office as heads of 12 sanjaks
column3: into which Egypt was divided; and under the next sultan
column4: Suleiman I
column5: two chambers were created
column6: called the Greater Divan and Lesser Divan
column7: in which both the army and the ecclesiastical authorities were represented
column8: to aid the pasha by their deliberations. Six regiments were constituted by the conqueror Selim for the protection of Egypt; to those Suleiman added a seventh
column9: of Circassians.It was the practice of the Sublime Porte to change the governor of Egypt at very short intervals
column10: after a year or less. The fourth governor
column11: Hain Ahmed Pasha
column12: hearing that orders for his execution had come from Constantinople
column13: endeavoured to make himself an independent ruler and had coins struck in his own name. His schemes were frustrated by two of the emirs whom he had imprisoned and who
column15: attacked him in his bath and attempted to kill him; although Ahmed Pasha escaped wounded
column16: he was soon captured and executed by the Ottoman sultan's forces.

column2: the first survey of Egypt under the Ottomans was made
column3: the official copy of the former registers having perished by fire; this new survey did not come into use until 1605. Egyptian lands were divided into four classes: the sultan's domain
column4: fiefs
column5: land for the maintenance of the army
column6: and lands settled on religious foundations.

column1: The constant changes in the government seem to have caused the army to get out of control at an early period of the Ottoman occupation
column2: and at the beginning of the 17th century mutinies became common; in 1604
column3: governor Maktul Hacı Ibrahim Pasha (then known just as Ibrahim Pasha) was murdered by the soldiers
column4: and his head set on the Bab Zuweila
column5: earning him the epithet Maktul
column6: "the Slain". The reason for these mutinies was the attempt made by successive pashas to put a stop to the extortion called the tulbah
column7: a forced payment exacted by the troops from the inhabitants of the country by the fiction of debts requiring to be discharged
column8: which led to grievous ill-usage.In 1609
column9: a conflict broke out between the army and the pasha
column10: who had loyal regiments on his side and the Bedouins. The soldiers went so far as to choose a sultan
column11: and to provisionally divide the regions of Cairo between them. They were defeated by the governor Kara Mehmed Pasha
column12: who
column17: earning him the nickname Kul Kıran ("Slavebreaker"). Historians speak of this event as a second conquest of Egypt for the Ottomans. A great financial reform was then effected by Kara Mehmed Pasha
column18: who readjusted the burdens imposed on the different communities of Egypt in accordance with their means.

column1: With the troubles that beset the metropolis of the Ottoman Empire
column2: the governors appointed thence came to be treated by the Egyptians with continually decreasing respect. In July 1623
column3: an order came from the Porte dismissing Kara Mustafa Pasha
column4: and appointing Çeşteci Ali Pasha governor in his place. The officers met the deputy of the newly appointed governor and demanded from him the customary gratuity; when the deputy refused
column5: they sent letters to the Porte declaring that they wished to have Kara Mustafa Pasha
column6: and not Çeşteci Ali Pasha
column7: as governor. Meanwhile
column8: Çeşteci Ali Pasha had arrived at Alexandria and was met by a deputation from Cairo telling him that he was not wanted. He returned a mild answer; when a rejoinder came in the same style as the first message
column9: he had the leader of the deputation arrested and imprisoned. The garrison of Alexandria then attacked the castle and rescued the prisoner
column10: whereupon Çeşteci Ali Pasha was compelled to reembark on his ship and escape. Shortly thereafter
column11: a rescript arrived from Constantinople confirming Kara Mustafa Pasha in the governorship. Mustafa was succeeded by Bayram Pasha in 1626.

column1: Officers in the Ottoman Egyptian army were appointed locally from the various militias
column2: and had strong ties to the Egyptian aristocracy. Thus Ridwan Bey
column3: a Mamluk emir
column4: was able to exercise de facto authority over Egypt from 1631 to 1656. In 1630
column5: Koca Musa Pasha was the newly appointed governor
column6: when the army took it upon themselves to depose him
column7: in indignation at his execution of Kits Bey
column8: an officer who was to have commanded an Egyptian force required for service in Persia. Koca Musa Pasha was given the choice of handing over the executioners to vengeance
column9: or to resigning his place; as he refused to do the former
column10: he was compelled to do the latter. In 1631
column11: a rescript came from Constantinople
column12: approving the conduct of the army and appointing Halil Pasha as Koca Musa Pasha's successor. Not only was the governor unsupported by the sultan against the troops
column13: but each new governor regularly inflicted a fine upon his outgoing predecessor
column14: under the name of money due to the treasury; the outgoing governor would not be allowed to leave Egypt until he had paid it. Besides the extortions to which this practice gave occasion
column15: the country suffered greatly in these centuries from famine and pestilence. In the spring of 1619
column16: pestilence is said to have killed 635

column2: the importance of the pasha was superseded by that of the Mameluk beys; two offices
column3: those of Shaykh al-Balad and Amir al-hajj—which were held by Mameluks—represented the real headship of the community. The process by which this came about is obscure
column4: owing to the want of good chronicles for the Turkish period of Egyptian history. In 1707
column5: the shaykh al-balad
column6: Qasim Iywaz
column7: was the head of one of two Mameluke factions
column8: the Qasimites and the Fiqarites
column9: between whom the seeds of enmity were sown by the pasha of the time
column10: with the result that a fight took place between the factions outside Cairo
column11: lasting eighty days. At the end of that time
column12: Qasim Iywaz was killed and the office which he had held was given to his son Ismail. Ismail held this office for 16 years
column13: while the pashas were constantly being changed
column14: and succeeded in reconciling the two factions of Mamelukes. In 1711
column15: an event known to chroniclers as the "Great Sedition" and the "revolution" occurred
column16: when a religious fanatic preacher began to publicly denounce the practice of praying at the graves of Sufi saints
column17: sparking a religious movement that wasn't crushed for three years until 1714. In 1724
column18: Ismail was assassinated through the machinations of the pasha
column19: and Shirkas Bey—of the opposing faction—was elevated to the office of Sheikh al-Balad in his place. He was soon driven from his post by one of his own faction called Dhu-'l-Fiqar
column20: and fled to Upper Egypt. After a short time
column21: he returned at the head of an army
column22: and in the last of the ensuing battles Shirkas Bey met his end by drowning. Dhu-'l-Fiqar was himself assassinated in 1730. His place was filled by Othman Bey
column23: who had served as his general in this war.In 1743
column24: Othman Bey was forced to fly from Egypt by the intrigues of two adventurers
column26: who—when their scheme had succeeded—began a massacre of beys and others thought to be opposed to them. They proceeded to govern Egypt jointly
column27: holding the offices of Sheikh al-Balad and Amir al-Hajj in alternate years. An attempt by one of the pashas to remove these two by a coup d'état failed
column28: owing to the loyalty of the beys' armed supporters
column29: who released Ibrahim and Ridwan from prison and compelled the pasha to flee to Constantinople. An attempt by a subsequent pasha
column30: in accordance with secret orders from Constantinople
column31: was so successful that some of the beys were killed. Ibrahim and Rilwan escaped and compelled the pasha to resign his governorship and return to Constantinople. Ibrahim was assassinated shortly afterwards by someone who had aspired to occupy one of the vacant beyships
column32: which had instead been conferred upon Ali—who
column34: was destined to play an important part in the history of Egypt. The murder of Ibrahim Bey took place in 1755
column35: and his colleague Ridwan perished in the subsequent disputes.Ali Bey
column36: who had first distinguished himself by defending a caravan in Arabia against bandits
column37: set himself the task of avenging the death of his former master Ibraihim. He spent eight years in purchasing Mamelukes and winning other adherents
column38: exciting the suspicions of the Sheikh al-Balad Khalil Bey
column39: who organised an attack upon him in the streets of Cairo—in consequence of which he fled to Upper Egypt. Here he met one Salib Bey
column40: who had injuries to avenge upon Khalil Bey
column41: and the two organised a force with which they returned to Cairo and defeated Khalil. Kalil was forced to flee to Iaifla
column42: where for a time he concealed himself; eventually he was discovered
column44: and finally strangled. After Ali Bey's victory in 1760
column45: he was made Sheikh al-Balad. He executed the murderer of his former master Ibrahim; but the resentment which this act aroused among the beys caused him to leave his post and flee to Syria
column46: where he won the friendship of the governor of Acre
column48: who obtained for him the goodwill of the Porte and reinstatement in his post as Sheikh al-Balad.

column2: after the death of his supporter
column3: the grand vizier Raghib Pasha
column4: he was again compelled to flee from Egypt to Yemen
column5: but in the following year he was told that his party at Cairo was strong enough to permit his return. Resuming his office
column6: he raised 18 of his friends to the rank of bey—among them Ibrahim and Murad
column7: who were afterwards at the head of affairs—as well as Muhammad Abu-'l-Dhahab
column8: who was closely connected with the rest of Ali Bey's career. Ali Bey used very severe measures to repress the brigandage of the Bedouins of Lower Egypt. He endeavoured to disband all forces except those which were exclusively under his own control.In 1769
column9: a demand came to Ali Bey for a force of 12
column10: 000 men
column11: to be employed by the Porte in the Russo-Turkish War of 1768–1774. It was suggested at Constantinople
column12: however
column13: that Ali would employ this force when he collected it for securing his own independence
column14: and a messenger was sent by the Porte to the pasha with orders for Ali's execution. Ali
column15: being apprised of the despatch of this messenger by his agents in Constantinople
column16: ordered that the messenger be waylaid and killed. The despatches were seized and read by Ali before an assembly of the beys
column17: who were assured that the order for execution applied to all alike
column18: and he urged them to fight for their lives. His proposals were received with enthusiasm by the beys whom he had created. Egypt was declared independent
column19: and the pasha given 48 hours to quit the country. Zahir al-Umar
column21: to whom official information of the step taken by Ali Bey was sent
column22: promised his aid and kept his word by compelling an army sent by the pasha of Damascus against Egypt to retreat.

column1: The Porte was not able to take active measures at the time for the suppression of Ali Bey
column2: who endeavoured to consolidate his dominions by sending expeditions against marauding tribes in both north and south Egypt
column3: reforming the finance
column4: and improving the administration of justice. His son-in-law
column5: Abu-'l-Dhahab
column6: was sent to subject the Hawwara
column7: who had occupied the land between Aswan and Asyut
column8: and a force of 20
column9: 000 men was sent to conquer Yemen. An officer named Ismail Bey was sent with 8
column10: 000 men to acquire the eastern shore of the Red Sea
column11: and Ilasan Bey was sent to occupy Jidda. In six months
column12: the greater part of the Arabian peninsula was subject to Ali Bey
column13: and he appointed a cousin of his own as Sharif of Mecca—who bestowed on Ali by an official proclamation the titles Sultan of Egypt and Khan of the Two Seas. In 1771
column15: he then struck coins in his own name and ordered his name to be mentioned in public worship.Abu-'l-Dhahab was sent with a force of 30
column16: 000 men in the same year to conquer Syria
column17: and agents were sent to negotiate alliances with Venice and Russia. Reinforced by Ali Bey's ally Zahir al-Umar
column18: Abu-'l-Dahab easily took the chief cities of Palestine and Syria
column20: but at this point he appears to have entered into secret negotiations with the Porte
column21: by which he undertook to restore Egypt to Ottoman suzerainty. He proceeded to evacuate Syria
column22: and marched with all the forces he could collect to Upper Egypt
column23: occupying Assiut in April 1772. Having collected additional troops from the Bedouins
column24: he marched on Cairo. Ismail Bey was sent by Ali Bey with a force of 3
column26: but Bastin Ismil and his troops joined Abu-'l-Dhahab. Ali Bey intended at first to defend himself as long as possible in the citadel at Cairo
column27: but receiving information that his friend Zahir al-Umar was still willing to give him refuge
column28: he left Cairo for Syria on 8 April 1772
column29: one day before the entrance of Abu-'l-Dhahab.

column2: Ali's fortune seemed to be restored. A Russian vessel anchored outside the port and
column3: in accordance with the agreement which he had made with the Russian empire
column4: he was supplied with stores
column5: ammunition
column6: and a force of 3
column7: 000 Albanians. He sent one of his officers
column8: Ali Bey al-Tantawi
column9: to recover the Syrian towns evacuated by Abu-'l-Dhahab now in the possession of the Porte. He himself took Jaffa and Gaza
column10: the former of which he gave to his friend Zahir al-Umar. On 1 February 1773
column11: he received information from Cairo that Abu-'l-Dhahab had made himself Sheikh al-Balad
column12: and in that capacity was practising unheard-of extortions
column13: which were making Egyptians call for the return of Ali Bey. He accordingly started for Egypt at the head of an army of 8
column15: and on 19 April met the army of Abu-'l-Dhahab at Salihiyya Madrasa. Ali's forces were successful at the first engagement
column16: but when the battle was renewed two days later
column17: he was deserted by some of his officers and prevented by illness and wounds from himself taking the conduct of affairs. The result was a complete defeat for his army
column18: after which he declined to leave his tent; he was captured after a brave resistance and taken to Cairo
column19: where he died seven days later.After Ali Bey's death
column20: Egypt became once more a dependency of the Porte
column21: governed by Abu-'l-Dhahab as Sheikh al-Balad with the title pasha. He shortly afterwards received permission from the Porte to invade Syria
column22: with the view of punishing Ali Bey's supporter Zahir al-Umar
column23: and left Ismail Bey and Ibrahim Bey as his deputies in Cairo—who
column24: by deserting Ali at the battle of Salihiyya
column25: had brought about his downfall. After taking many cities in Palestine
column27: the cause being unknown; Murad Bey
column28: another of the deserters at Salihiyya
column29: brought his forces back to Egypt on 26 May 1775.

column1: Ismail Bey now became Sheikh al-Balad
column2: but was soon involved in a dispute with Ibrahim and Murad—who
column3: after a time
column4: succeeded in driving Ismail out of Egypt and establishing a joint rule similar to that which had been tried previously (as Sheikh al-Balad and Amir al-Hajj
column5: respectively). The two were soon involved in quarrels
column6: which at one time threatened to break out into open war
column7: but this catastrophe was averted and the joint rule was maintained until 1786
column8: when an expedition was sent by the Porte to restore Ottoman supremacy in Egypt. Murad Bey attempted to resist
column9: but was easily defeated. He
column10: with Ibrahim
column11: decided to flee to Upper Egypt and await the trend of events. On 1 August
column12: the Turkish commander Cezayirli Gazi Hasan Pasha entered Cairo
column14: had been taken for the restoration of order; Ismail Bey was again made Sheikh al-Balad and a new pasha installed as governor. In January 1791
column15: a terrible plague raged in Cairo and elsewhere in Egypt
column16: to which Ismail Bey and most of his family fell victims. Owing to the need for competent rulers
column17: Ibrahim Bey and Murad Bey were sent for
column18: and resumed their dual government. They were still in office in 1798 when Napoleon Bonaparte entered Egypt.

column1: The ostensible object of the French expedition to Egypt was to reinstate the authority of the Sublime Porte and suppress the Mamluks; in the proclamation
column2: printed with the Arabic types brought from the Propaganda press and issued shortly after the taking of Alexandria
column3: Bonaparte declared that he revered God
column4: the prophet Muhammad
column5: and the Qur'an far more than the Mamluks revered them
column6: and argued that all men were equal except so far as they were distinguished by their intellectual and moral excellences—of which the Mamluks had no great share. In the future
column7: all posts in Egypt were to be open to all classes of the inhabitants; the conduct of affairs was to be committed to the men of talent
column8: virtue
column9: and learning; and to prove that the French were sincere Muslims
column10: the overthrow of the papal authority in Rome was suggested.

column1: That there might be no doubt of the friendly feeling of the French to the Porte
column2: villages and towns which capitulated to the invaders were required to hoist the flags of both the Porte and the French republic
column3: and in the thanksgiving prescribed to the Egyptians for their deliverance from the Mamluks
column4: prayer was to be offered for both the sultan and the French army. It does not appear that the proclamation convinced many Egyptians of the truth of these professions. After the Battle of Embabeh (also commonly known as the Battle of the Pyramids)
column5: at which the forces of both Murad Bey and Ibrahim Bey were dispersed
column6: the populace readily plundered the houses of the beys. A deputation was sent from al-Azhar to Bonaparte to ascertain his intentions; these proved to be a repetition of the terms of his proclamation
column7: and—though the combination of loyalty to the French with loyalty to the sultan was unintelligible—a good understanding was at first established between the invaders and the Egyptians.A municipal council was established in Cairo
column8: consisting of persons taken from the ranks of the sheiks
column9: the Mamluks
column10: and the French. Soon after
column11: delegates from Alexandria and other important towns were added. This council did little more than register the decrees of the French commander
column12: who continued to exercise dictatorial power.

column1: The destruction of the French fleet at the Battle of the Nile
column2: and the failure of the French forces sent to Upper Egypt (where they reached the first cataract) to obtain possession of the person of Murad Bey
column3: shook the faith of the Egyptians in their invincibility. In consequence of a series of unwelcome innovations
column4: the relations between conquerors and conquered grew more strained daily
column5: until at last—on the occasion of the introduction of a house tax on 22 October 1798—an insurrection broke out in Cairo. The headquarters of the insurrection were in the University of Azhar. On this occasion
column6: the French general Dupuy
column7: lieutenant-governor of Cairo
column8: was killed. The prompt measures of Bonaparte
column9: aided by the arrival from Alexandria of General Jean Baptiste Kléber
column10: quickly suppressed this rising; but the stabling of French cavalry in the mosque of Azhar gave great and permanent offence.In consequence of this affair
column11: the deliberative council was suppressed
column12: but on 25 December a fresh proclamation was issued reconstituting the two divans which had been created by the Turks; the special divan was to consist of 14 persons chosen by lot out of 60 government nominees
column13: and was to meet daily. The general divan was to consist of functionaries
column14: and to meet on emergencies.In consequence of dispatches that reached Bonaparte on 3 January 1799
column15: announcing the intention of the Porte to invade the country with the object of recovering it by force
column16: Bonaparte resolved on his Syrian expedition

column1: Bonaparte returned from that ill-fated expedition at the beginning of June. Murad Bey and Ibrahim Bey had taken advantage of this opportunity to collect their forces and attempt a joint attack on Cairo
column2: but Bonaparte arrived in time to defeat it. In the last week of July
column3: he inflicted a crushing defeat on the Turkish army that had landed at Aboukir
column4: aided by the British fleet commanded by Sir Sidney Smith.Shortly after his victory
column5: Bonaparte left Egypt
column6: having appointed Kléber to govern in his absence—which he informed the sheiks of Cairo was not to last more than three months. Kléber regarded the condition of the French invaders as extremely perilous
column7: and wrote to inform the French republic of the facts. A double expedition was sent by the Porte shortly after Bonaparte's departure for the recovery of Egypt: one force being dispatched by sea to Damietta
column8: while another under Yousuf Pasha took the land route from Damascus by al-Arish. The first force had some success
column9: in consequence of which the Turks agreed to a convention on 24 January 1800
column10: by virtue of which the French were to quit Egypt. The Turkish troops advanced to Bilbeis
column11: where they were received by the sheiks from Cairo; the Mamluks also returned to Cairo from their hiding-places.Before the preparations for the departure of the French were completed
column12: orders came to Smith from the British government forbidding the carrying-out of the convention unless the French army were treated as prisoners of war. When these orders were communicated to Kléber
column13: he cancelled the orders previously given to the troops and proceeded to put the country in a state of defence. His departure
column15: to attack the Turks at Mataria led to riots in Cairo. The national party was unable to gain possession of the citadel
column18: was soon able to return to the capital. On 14 April he bombarded Bulaq
column19: and proceeded to bombard Cairo itself
column20: which was taken the following night. Order was soon restored
column21: and a fine of 12 million francs was imposed upon the rioters. Murad Bey sought an interview with Kléber
column22: and succeeded in obtaining the government of Upper Egypt from him. Murad Bey died shortly afterwards and was succeeded by Osman Bey al-Bardisi.

column2: Kléber was assassinated by Suleiman al-Halabi
column3: and was said to have been incited to the deed by a Janissary refugee at Jerusalem
column4: who had brought letters to the sheikhs of the Azhar. Although they gave him no support
column5: three of the sheikhs were executed by the French as accessories-before-the-fact. The assassin himself was tortured and impaled
column6: despite the promise of a pardon if he named his associates. The command of the army then devolved on General J.F. (Baron de) Menou
column7: a man who had professed Islam
column8: and who endeavoured to conciliate the Muslim population by various measures—such as excluding all Christians (with the exception of one Frenchman) from the divan
column9: replacing Copts who were in government service with Muslims
column10: and subjecting French residents to taxes. Whatever popularity might have been gained by these measures was counteracted by his declaration of a French protectorate over Egypt
column11: which was to count as a French colony.

column1: In the first weeks of March 1801
column2: the English under Sir Ralph Abercromby effected a landing at Abu Qir
column3: and proceeded to invest Alexandria
column4: where they were attacked by Menou; the French were repulsed
column5: but the English commander was mortally wounded in the action. On the 25th
column6: fresh Turkish reinforcements arrived with the fleet of the Kapudan Pasha Hüseyin. A combined English and Turkish force was sent to take Rashid. On 30 May
column7: General A. D. Belliard
column8: the French commander in Cairo
column9: was assailed on two sides by British forces under General John Hely Hutchinson and Turks under Yusuf Pasha; after negotiations
column10: Belliard agreed to evacuate Cairo and to sail with his 13
column11: 734 troops to France. On 30 August
column12: Menou was compelled to accept similar conditions
column14: 000 left Alexandria for Europe in September. This was the termination of the French occupation of Egypt. The chief permanent monument of the occupation was the Description de l'Egypte
column15: compiled by the French savants who accompanied the expedition.

column1: Soon after the French evacuated Egypt
column2: the country became the scene of more severe troubles
column3: a consequence of the Ottomans' attempts to destroy the power of the Mamluks. In defiance of promises to the British Government
column4: orders were transmitted from Constantinople to Hüseyin Pasha to ensnare and put to death the principal beys. According to the Egyptian contemporary historian al-Jabarti
column5: they were invited to an entertainment on board the Turkish flagship and then attacked; however
column6: Sir Robert Wilson and M.F. Mengin stated that they were fired upon in open boats in Abu Qir Bay. They offered resistance
column7: but were overpowered
column8: and some killed; others were made prisoners. Among the prisoners was Osman Bey al-Bardisi
column9: who was severely wounded. The British General Hutchinson
column10: informed of this treachery
column11: immediately took threatening measures against the Turks
column12: causing them to surrender the killed
column14: and imprisoned Egyptians to him. At the same time
column15: Yusuf Pasha arrested all the beys in Cairo
column16: but soon the British compelled him to release them.

column1: Husrev Pasha was the first Ottoman governor of Egypt after the expulsion of the French. The form of government
column2: however
column3: was not the same as that before the French invasion
column4: for the Mamluks were not reinstated. The pasha
column5: and through him the Sultan
column6: repeatedly tried to either ensnare them or to beguile them into submission. These efforts failing
column7: Husrev took the field and a Turkish detachment 7
column8: 000 strong was dispatched against the Mamluks to Damanhur—whence they had descended from Upper Egypt—and was defeated by a small force under either al-Alfi or his lieutenant al-Bardisi. Their ammunition and guns fell into the hands of the Mamluks. This led to a long civil war between the Albanians
column9: Mamluks
column10: and Ottomans.

column1: Acknowledging the sovereignty of the Ottoman Sultan and at his command
column2: Muhammad Ali dispatched an army of 20
column3: 000 men (including 2
column4: 000 horses) under the command of his son Tusun
column5: a youth of sixteen
column6: against the Saudis in the Ottoman–Saudi War. By the end of 1811
column7: Tusun had received reinforcements and captured Medina after a prolonged siege. He next took Jeddah and Mecca
column8: defeating the Saudi beyond the latter and capturing their general.

column1: After the death of the Saudi leader Saud
column2: Muhammad Ali concluded a treaty with Saud's son and successor
column3: Abdullah I in 1815.Tusun returned to Egypt on hearing of the military revolt at Cairo
column4: but died in 1816 at the early age of twenty. Muhammad Ali
column5: dissatisfied with the treaty concluded with the Saudis
column6: and with the non-fulfillment of certain of its clauses
column7: determined to send another army to Arabia. This expedition
column8: under his eldest son Ibrahim Pasha
column9: left in the autumn of 1816 and captured the Saudi capital of Diriyah in 1818.

column1: During Muhammad Ali's absence in Arabia his representative at Cairo had completed the confiscation
column2: begun in 1808
column3: of almost all the lands belonging to private individuals
column4: who were forced to accept instead inadequate pensions. By this revolutionary method of land nationalization Muhammad Ali became proprietor of nearly all the soil of Egypt. The pasha also attempted to reorganize his troops on European lines
column5: but this led to a formidable mutiny in Cairo. The revolt was reduced by presents to the chiefs of the insurgents
column6: and Muhammad Ali ordered that the sufferers by the disturbances should receive compensation from the treasury. The project of the Nizam Gedid (New System) was
column7: in consequence of this mutiny
column8: abandoned for a time.While Ibrahim was engaged in the second Arabian campaign the pasha turned his attention to strengthening the Egyptian economy. He created state monopolies over the chief products of the country. He set up a number of factories and began digging in 1819 a new canal to Alexandria
column9: called the Mahmudiya (after the reigning sultan of Turkey). The old canal had long fallen into decay
column10: and the necessity of a safe channel between Alexandria and the Nile was much felt. The conclusion in 1838 of a commercial treaty with Turkey
column11: negotiated by Sir Henry Bulwer (Lord Darling)
column12: struck a deathblow to the system of monopolies
column13: though the application of the treaty to Egypt was delayed for some years.Another notable fact in the economic progress of the country was the development of the cultivation of cotton in the Delta in 1822 and onwards. The cotton grown previously had been brought from the Sudan by Maho Bey. By organizing the new industry
column14: within a few years Muhammad Ali was able to extract considerable revenues.

column1: Efforts were made to promote education and the study of medicine. To European merchants
column2: on whom he was dependent for the sale of his exports

column4: and under his influence the port of Alexandria again rose into importance. It was also under Muhammad Ali's encouragement that the overland transit of goods from Europe to India via Egypt was resumed.Sultan Mahmud II was also planning reforms borrowed from the West
column5: and Muhammad Ali

The effectiveness of the new force was demonstrated in the suppression of an 1823 revolt of the Albanians in Cairo by six disciplined Sudanese regiments; after which Mehemet Ali was no more troubled with military mutinies.

column1: Egypt under Muhammad Ali in the early 19th century had the fifth most productive cotton industry in the world
column2: in terms of the number of spindles per capita. The industry was initially driven by machinery that relied on traditional energy sources
column3: such as animal power
column4: water wheels
column5: and windmills
column6: which were also the principle energy sources in Western Europe up until around 1870. While steam power had been experimented with in Ottoman Egypt by engineer Taqi ad-Din Muhammad ibn Ma'ruf in 1551
column7: when he invented a steam jack driven by a rudimentary steam turbine
column8: it was under Muhammad Ali in the early 19th century that steam engines were introduced to Egyptian industrial manufacturing. While there was a lack of coal deposits in Egypt
column9: prospectors searched for coal deposits there
column10: and manufactured boilers which were installed in Egyptian industries such as ironworks
column11: textile manufacturing
column12: paper mills and hulling mills. Coal was also imported from overseas
column13: at similar prices to what imported coal cost in France
column15: when Egypt gained access to coal sources in Lebanon
column16: which had a yearly coal output of 4
column18: Egypt also had superior agriculture and an efficient transport network through the Nile. Economic historian Jean Batou argues that the necessary economic conditions for rapid industrialization existed in Egypt during the 1820s–1830s
column19: as well as for the adoption of oil as a potential energy source for its steam engines later in the 19th century.

column1: In 1820 Muhammad Ali gave orders to commence the conquest of eastern Libya. Ali's intentions for Sudan was to extend his rule southward

column3: disperse Mamluks who have fled south

column7: 000 and 5
column8: 000 men

column4: Pasha of Egypt

column1: In 1824 a native rebellion broke out in Upper Egypt headed by Ahmed
column2: an inhabitant of al-Salimiyyah

column4: and was soon followed by between 20
column6: 000 insurgents

column1: Ali's foresight in reforming his military forces was rewarded by the invitation of the sultan to help him in the task of subduing the Greek insurgents

column4: and

column11: who early in August 1828 appeared before Alexandria and induced the pash to sign a convention undertaking to recall Ibrahim and his army.

column1: Ali went to war against the sultan on pretext of chastising the ex-mamluk Abdullah Pasha of Acre
column2: for refusing to send back Egyptian fugitives from the effects of Muhammad Ali's reforms. The true reason was the refusal of Sultan Mahmud to hand over Syria according to agreement.

column1: For ten years from this date the relations of sultan and pasha remained in the forefront of the questions which agitated the diplomatic world. It was not only the very existence of the Ottoman Empire that seemed to be at stake
column2: but Egypt itself had become more than ever an object of attention
column3: to British statesmen especially
column4: and in the issue of the struggle were involved the interests of the British Empire in the two routes to India by the Isthmus of Suez and the valley of the Euphrates.Ibrahim
column5: who once more commanded in his father's name
column6: launched another brilliant campaign beginning with the storming of Acre on 27 May 1832
column7: and culminating in the rout and capture of Reshid Pasha at Konya on 21 December.

column3: the Porte and the pasha

column5: by which the sultan agreed to bestow on Muhammad Ali the pashaliks of Syria
column6: Damascus
column7: Aleppo and Itcheli

column9: subject only to a moderate tribute

column19: to advance over the Syrian frontier. Ibrahim

column27: Muhammad Ali had reached the height of his power
column30: and Syria. He saw the Ottoman armies collapse or fall into disorganization after their defeat in Syria
column31: and it looked like the Middle East and Anatolia were his for the taking.With the Ottoman Empire at the feet of Muhammad Ali
column32: the European powers were greatly alarmed and now put into action a plan that had been prepared to meet a contingency which had been long foreseen. Their intervention during the Oriental Crisis of 1840 was prompt
column33: and they made short work of Muhammad Ali's armed forces. But the Western Powers

column1: The government of the pashalik of Egypt was made hereditary in the family of Muhammad Ali in 1841.Various restrictions were laid upon Muhammad Ali
column2: emphasizing his position as vassal. He was forbidden to maintain a fleet and his army was not to exceed 18
column3: 000 men. The pasha was no longer a figure in European politics
column4: but he continued to occupy himself with his improvements in Egypt. The long wars combined with a murrain of cattle in 1842 and a destructive Nile flood. In 1843 there was a plague of locusts where whole villages were depopulated.In 1844–45 there was some improvement in the condition of the country as a result of financial reforms the pasha executed. Muhammad Ali

column7: where he became reconciled to his old enemy Khosrev Pasha
column8: whom he had not seen since he spared his life at Cairo in 1803. In 1847 Muhammad Ali laid the foundation stone of the great bridge across the Nile at the beginning of the Delta. Towards the end of 1847
column9: the aged pasha's previously sharp mind began to give way
column10: and by the following June he was no longer capable of administering the government. In September 1848 Ibrahim was acknowledged by the Porte as ruler of the pashalik
column11: but he died in November.

column1: On Ibrahim's death in November 1848 the government of Egypt fell to his nephew Abbas I
column2: the son of Tusun Abbasad. Abbas put an end to the system of commercial monopolies
column3: and during his reign the railway from Alexandria to Cairo was begun at the instigation of the British government. Opposed to European ways
column4: Abbas lived in great seclusion. After a reign of less than six years he was murdered in July 1854 by two of his slaves.He was succeeded by his uncle Said Pasha
column5: the favorite son of Muhammad Ali
column6: who lacked the strength of mind or physical health needed to execute the beneficent projects which he conceived.

column1: He had a genuine regard for the welfare of the fellahin

column3: and in 1854 was induced to grant to the French engineer Ferdinand de Lesseps a concession for the construction of the Suez Canal.In January 1863 Said Pasha died and was succeeded by his nephew Ismail
column4: a son of Ibrahim Pasha.The reign of Ismail
column5: from 1863 to 1879

column7: but these coupled with his personal extravagance led to bankruptcy

column9: and occupation of

column1: This control of the country was unacceptable to many Egyptians
column2: who united behind a disaffected Colonel Ahmed Urabi. The Urabi Revolt consumed Egypt. With the country largely in the hands of Urabi

column1: A large military demonstration in September 1881 forced the Khedive Tewfiq to dismiss his Prime Minister. In April 1882 France and Great Britain sent warships to Alexandria to bolster the Khedive amidst a turbulent climate. Tawfiq moved to Alexandria for fear of his own safety as army officers led by Ahmed Urabi began to take control of the government. By June Egypt was in the hands of nationalists opposed to European domination of the country. A British naval bombardment of Alexandria had little effect on the opposition which led to the landing of a British expeditionary force at both ends of the Suez Canal in August 1882. The British succeeded in defeating the Egyptian Army at Tel El Kebir in September and took control of the country putting Tawfiq back in control. The Khedivate of Egypt remained under British military occupation until the establishment of the British protectorate of Egypt in 1914.
